SELF » Fitness News http://www.self.com SELF Magazine: Fashion, Workouts, Beauty, Recipes, Fitness Tips and More Thu, 12 May 2016 22:23:04 +0000 en-US hourly 1 This Women’s Running Cover Star Won’t Let Epilepsy Or Autism Stop Her http://www.self.com/fitness/fitness-news/2015/12/this-womens-running-cover-star-wont-let-epilepsy-or-autism-stop-her/ http://www.self.com/fitness/fitness-news/2015/12/this-womens-running-cover-star-wont-let-epilepsy-or-autism-stop-her/#comments Tue, 01 Dec 2015 19:54:50 +0000 http://www.self.com/?p=1172971 "When I run it relieves so much stress on my brain."

The post This Women’s Running Cover Star Won’t Let Epilepsy Or Autism Stop Her appeared first on SELF.

]]> This Women’s Running cover star won’t let a little thing like epileptic seizures get in the way of her goals.  

Autism doesn’t stop our Cover Runner Contest winner Kiley. Behind the scenes of her cover. https://t.co/evWgb8x7q1 pic.twitter.com/XVw141THF5

— Women’s Running (@WomensRunning) December 1, 2015

Kiley Lyall, age 24, was one of 4,000 entrants to the magazine’s third annual Cover Runner Contest, where women applied to be featured on the magazine’s January/February 2016 cover. In her entry submission, she explained that she “just happens to live with moderate autism and life-threatening seizures” related to epilepsy, as well as mild cerebral palsy. 

“Running has literally helped my brain become healthier,” Lyall explained in her competition entry. “My autism doesn’t take over my days anymore…when I run it relieves so much stress on my brain, allowing me to function much better through most days!”

Women’s Running editor-in-chief Jessie Sebor said that she was moved by Lyall’s toughness. During her first half-marathon, Lyall had two seizures–and insisted on finishing the race anyway.

“We’re so passionate about this cover and the opportunity to share Kiley’s story of determination,” she said in an article about the cover. “Our readers know that a love of running steams from many different places and sentiments. We want to support all women on their running journey.”

Congratulations, Kiley!

The post This Women’s Running Cover Star Won’t Let Epilepsy Or Autism Stop Her appeared first on SELF.

via giphy

By signing up now you can enter for a chance to win a luxe beach vacation…which is the best reason to use the palm tree and sun emojis during winter.

]]> http://www.self.com/fitness/fitness-news/2015/11/10-reasons-why-you-should-sign-up-for-the-selfxtone-it-up-challenge/feed/ 0 Two Fitness Instructors Gave A Brilliant Response After Being Body Shamed http://www.self.com/fitness/fitness-news/2015/11/two-fitness-instructors-gave-a-brilliant-response-after-being-body-shamed/ http://www.self.com/fitness/fitness-news/2015/11/two-fitness-instructors-gave-a-brilliant-response-after-being-body-shamed/#comments Tue, 10 Nov 2015 19:07:43 +0000 http://www.self.com/?p=1171035 "I think she's done us all a favor by starting this conversation."

The post Two Fitness Instructors Gave A Brilliant Response After Being Body Shamed appeared first on SELF.

]]> Fitness instructor Megan Ellis is the co-manager of the Barre East Fitness Studio in Frederick, Maryland.

Photo by Brodie Ledford, courtesy of Taryn Sisco

When a newspaper clipping slid out of an envelope addressed to the studio Ellis wasn’t particularly surprised. The studio had just been featured in the business section of the local newspaper and she figured it was someone they knew sending them a copy.

But when she unfolded the clipping, what she saw brought her to tears.

Courtesy of Taryn Sisco

An arrow pointing to Ellis’ hips reads: “You are fat, bordering on obese.” Another arrow connects co-manager and fellow instructor Taryn Sisco’s head to the words “You are overweight.”

The post Two Fitness Instructors Gave A Brilliant Response After Being Body Shamed appeared first on SELF.

]]> http://www.self.com/fitness/fitness-news/2015/11/two-fitness-instructors-gave-a-brilliant-response-after-being-body-shamed/feed/ 0 People Are Doing Hot Barre Workouts Now And Here’s What You Need To Know http://www.self.com/fitness/fitness-news/2015/10/hot-workout-classes-benefits-dangers/ http://www.self.com/fitness/fitness-news/2015/10/hot-workout-classes-benefits-dangers/#comments Fri, 23 Oct 2015 13:30:07 +0000 http://www.self.com/?p=1170112 Feeling hot hot hot!

The post People Are Doing Hot Barre Workouts Now And Here’s What You Need To Know appeared first on SELF.

]]> “I love the sweating part,” says Melanie Hendel, 31, an architect who goes to heated yoga classes at Lyons Den studio in New York City almost every day. “It feels amazing walking out of class—you see the evidence of working at a high intensity.” Enthusiasts like Hendel have helped make Bikram and other hot yoga classes ubiquitous nationwide. Now the “heated” trend is expanding to all kinds of studios, from barre to boxing. Most sessions of the heated boot camp classes at Body Heat Hot Pilates and Yoga in Rocklin, California, have a waiting list; business has gone up 30 percent each year at hot-cycling studio Sweat Shoppe in Los Angeles.

Our desire to feel flushed and dripping with sweat isn’t new; ancient Roman baths with steam rooms became de rigueur in 25 B.C. And when it comes to heat and exercise, it turns out there are benefits—just don’t count on burning exponentially more calories. “The body has to work a little harder to cool itself off when you exercise in the heat, so hot workouts may increase the metabolic load a bit, but they won’t dramatically increase the calories burned,” says Brian Tracy, Ph.D., associate professor of health and exercise science at Colorado State University. A comparison of two studies (one on Bikram yoga, one on traditional yoga) suggests that steamy classes burn only about 35 more calories than room-temp sessions over a 45-minute period.

Also, it’s tough to give it your all when you’re roasting. That factor could actually lower your calorie burn in an indoor cycling or boxing class. “Training suffers when you’re in very hot conditions all the time,” says Christopher Minson, Ph.D., codirector of the University of Oregon’s exercise and environmental physiology labs. “You get overheated and can’t exert as much effort, so that diminishes your performance.”

On the upside, hot workouts do seem to have benefits for your athletic performance. Cyclists who rode in the heat over 10 days boosted their hot- and cold-weather pace by 6 percent, according to a study by Minson. The reason: Not only were they more efficient at sweating (i.e., better at keeping their bodies cool), but their hearts also got better at delivering blood to their working muscles, and they raised their lactate threshold. (Minson recommends doing easy days in the heat so you get the acclimatization payoff without sacrificing effort in key workouts like speed sessions.)

The post People Are Doing Hot Barre Workouts Now And Here’s What You Need To Know appeared first on SELF.

]]> http://www.self.com/fitness/fitness-news/2015/10/hot-workout-classes-benefits-dangers/feed/ 0 Why Dumbbells Are The New Trend In Yoga http://www.self.com/fitness/fitness-news/2015/10/yoga-cardio-dumbbells/ http://www.self.com/fitness/fitness-news/2015/10/yoga-cardio-dumbbells/#comments Thu, 22 Oct 2015 20:45:21 +0000 http://www.self.com/?p=1170076 Block, strap…five-pound weights?

The post Why Dumbbells Are The New Trend In Yoga appeared first on SELF.

]]> Via Facebook @CorePowerYoga

Well+Good shares more about this growing fitness trend.

Clear some extra space in your prop piles, yogis—sculpting on the mat is here to stay.

Although it’d be easy to write off classes that combine yoga and free weights as just another clever fitness fad (cat yoga, anyone?), especially given the practice’s spiritual side, yoga sculpt classes have become fixtures on the wellness scene. Particularly in Los Angeles, where you’ll spy it at hot studios (CorePower, Hot 8) and non-sweaty ones (Red Diamond, Revolution Fitness)—and at established destinations (Earth’s Power Yoga, YAS) as well as newer arrivals (Aura,Evoke). It’s also happening across the country…

So what’s big draw of adding light weights to your flow?

“Weights add a little bit of intensity [to a yoga practice]… and in LA, people are always looking for something that’s very challenging,” explains Brit Middleton, yoga director at Hot 8, a heated yoga studio with locations in Santa Monica and Beverly Hills. Both locations offer a weighted sculpting class that promises to build lean muscle mass and boost metabolism (at 107 degree temperatures, no less).

Although sculpt classes are different studio to studio, they all blend traditional strength training moves with yoga postures—think bicep curls with your legs in crescent pose, or weighted squats in chair.

The post Why Dumbbells Are The New Trend In Yoga appeared first on SELF.

It’s Friday afternoon and happy hour is calling. Since you have a few more hours before you can head out for the weekend (without suspicious side-eye from colleagues), pop on your headphones and watch this clip from The Late Show With Stephen Colbert. The video features a solo from now principal dancer at American Ballet Theatre Misty Copeland while cellist Yo-Yo Ma plays. The performance…magical.

]]> http://www.self.com/fitness/fitness-news/2015/10/misty-copeland-performance-late-show-with-stephen-colbert/feed/ 0 Watch An 8-Year-Old Personal Trainer Do Push-Ups And Race Against Usain Bolt http://www.self.com/fitness/fitness-news/2015/10/eight-year-old-personal-trainer-push-ups-race-usain-bolt/ http://www.self.com/fitness/fitness-news/2015/10/eight-year-old-personal-trainer-push-ups-race-usain-bolt/#comments Thu, 08 Oct 2015 18:30:50 +0000 http://www.self.com/?p=1169433 He does 90 push-ups a day.

The post Watch An 8-Year-Old Personal Trainer Do Push-Ups And Race Against Usain Bolt appeared first on SELF.

]]> Six-time Olympic champion Usain Bolt found himself up against an unlikely opponent this week on The Ellen DeGeneres Show…eight-year-old Demarjay Smith.

Ellen invited Smith on her show after watching his fitness YouTube videos. Possibly the world’s youngest personal trainer, he shared his love of exercising and a few of his top push-up form tips. “I’ve got to be fit and strong,” he says while casually mentioning he does 90 push-ups a day. 90!

In addition to being a personal trainer and playing basketball when he grows up, Smith said he wants to challenge Usain Bolt to a race. In typical Ellen fashion, Smith got the surprise of his life when the Jamaican track star walked in for a running showdown. “Come on Usain, don’t be scared of me!” Smith yelled.

While Bolt happened to cramp up just before reaching the finish line, the track star was a good sport and congratulated Smith on his victory. Watch the fun clip below:

 

Usain Bolt may have just lost his title as the fastest man on Earth.

Posted by Ellen DeGeneres on Wednesday, 7 October 2015

The post Watch An 8-Year-Old Personal Trainer Do Push-Ups And Race Against Usain Bolt appeared first on SELF.

]]> http://www.self.com/fitness/fitness-news/2015/09/things-discovered-tone-it-up-retreat/feed/ 0 Skip Your Regular Workout Tomorrow and Check Out This Free Fitness Event http://www.self.com/fitness/fitness-news/2015/09/skip-your-workout-check-out-free-fitness-event/ http://www.self.com/fitness/fitness-news/2015/09/skip-your-workout-check-out-free-fitness-event/#comments Wed, 23 Sep 2015 20:00:57 +0000 http://www.self.com/?p=1168190 You'll still be home in time for Scandal.

The post Skip Your Regular Workout Tomorrow and Check Out This Free Fitness Event appeared first on SELF.

]]> Cancel your plans for tomorrow night and head to your nearest New Balance store for a one-night only fitness event. The activewear line has planned a “Strength is Beauty” series of activities featuring workouts, music, healthy snacks, talks and giveaways all geared towards celebrating strong women. The 46 events are happening at 50 different locations, so you’ll have no problem finding a different kind of happy hour tomorrow.

In addition to the Thursday events, New Balance is launching NB Women this fall. The collection is all about giving you the tools you need to perform at your peak, whether you’re trudging through burpees or sprinting on the track. “Finally, women are embracing fitness as a lifestyle, and are leaving behind the notion that fitness is only for the purpose of becoming skinny,” New Balance ambassador Holly Perkins, CSCS, who designed the strength training workout that will be featured at multiple stores for the event, tells SELF. “Women everywhere are embracing fitness as a means to be strong and express themselves.”

From the athletes who score hat tricks like it’s NBD to the endurance singers need to perform to the fit models who are rocking the runway, strong comes in all shapes and sizes. Raise a green juice and do another round of squats together tomorrow night.

The post Skip Your Regular Workout Tomorrow and Check Out This Free Fitness Event appeared first on SELF.

]]> http://www.self.com/fitness/fitness-news/2015/09/skip-your-workout-check-out-free-fitness-event/feed/ 0 Skier Lindsey Vonn Works Out Six Hours a Day, Six Days a Week—Even With a Broken Ankle http://www.self.com/fitness/fitness-news/2015/09/lindsey-vonn-workout-injury/ http://www.self.com/fitness/fitness-news/2015/09/lindsey-vonn-workout-injury/#comments Mon, 21 Sep 2015 19:00:52 +0000 http://www.self.com/?p=1168108 NBD.

The post Skier Lindsey Vonn Works Out Six Hours a Day, Six Days a Week—Even With a Broken Ankle appeared first on SELF.

]]> Lindsey Vonn just delivered the ultimate dose of #MondayMotivation. The Olympic downhill gold medalist and four-time World Cup champ revealed to Sports Illustrated that she spends six hours a day (five to six days per week) working out during the summertime. And this offseason prep is how she’s ready to crush it when she hits the slopes.  

The powerhouse athlete gives us serious gym envy on her Instagram, which is basically a how-to on staying motivated. Even with her recent injury (a broken ankle), Vonn has spent her summer planking on SUP boards, doing TRX by the pool, kickboxing, cycling and making some serious squat gains. She proves that the “gym” can really be, well, anywhere. And with a routine this badass, it’s no wonder she’s one of the most decorated skiers. 

But perhaps the real secret behind her workout routine and slope success is that she genuinely looks like she’s having fun—sweaty, exhausting fun. Channel the Olympic athlete’s motivation and you’ll have no problems getting #UpNOut all week (and winter!) long.

The post Skier Lindsey Vonn Works Out Six Hours a Day, Six Days a Week—Even With a Broken Ankle appeared first on SELF.

]]> The name says it all—you’re going to really earn it during this 30-minute workout. The new Cardio Hustle routine from Hong Kong-based Master Trainer Utah Lee launched last week on Nike’s NTC App. Think cardio drills, high knees, balance challenges and more that will have you training like an athlete. (Be sure to follow Lee on Instagram for major fitspo and sneaker envy.)

The high-intensity workout features heart-pumping, fast-paced intervals you can do anywhere. “I included a lot of footwork, agility and power movements. It’s fast. It keeps you pushing,” Lee tells Nike. 

While the cardio workout is a fat-burner, it will also help you become a better, speedier runner. 

Score the moves on the app (it’s free!)—then get ready to werk. Monday, you’ve just been owned.

The post This Quick Cardio Workout Will Burn Fat and Make You a Better Runner appeared first on SELF.

]]>

Ellie Goulding is a fit goddess. While scrolling her Instagram account you can see evidence of her inspiring workout skills—she masters every move from boxing to burpees. But she shared a fitness confession we can relate to: triceps are her weakest muscle, which makes those push-up and dips extra challenging. In true Goulding form, she proves that she’s up for the challenge—and willing to work hard for that strong, toned physique.

Goulding proves that sometimes the workout or exercise you hate is the one you need the most. And we love Goulding’s refreshingly honest approach to working out and eating healthy—“Not all green juices taste great,” she recently admitted. #healthtruthbomb

But all of that hard work is paying off, and she has more than one reason to celebrate—today she dropped a killer new single “On My Mind.” Listen below, then do a few push-ups!

]]> http://www.self.com/fitness/fitness-news/2015/09/ellie-goulding-new-song-on-my-mind/feed/ 0 The Truth About That Pilates Article http://www.self.com/fitness/fitness-news/2015/09/truth-about-pilates/ http://www.self.com/fitness/fitness-news/2015/09/truth-about-pilates/#comments Wed, 16 Sep 2015 19:45:36 +0000 http://www.self.com/?p=1167908 The traditional training style is getting a trendy makeover.

The post The Truth About That Pilates Article appeared first on SELF.

]]> Yesterday we read an article predicting the end of Pilates. The “Pilatespocalypse,” it said—and we beg to differ.

This end-is-near thought is based in the fact that people are craving intense, sweat-dripping sessions that don’t necessary come from doing “the Pilates 100.” Fair enough. But the results speak for themselves: Ballet dancers flock to this workout style to build core strength and shape stunning physiques

Sure, maybe traditional Pilates isn’t as edgy or trendy as some of the latest classes (many which fuse their signature styles with Pilates-based principals). But, we don’t think Pilates is dying; we think it’s just evolving.

Studios such as SLT and Brooklyn Bodyburn continue to rack up major buzz using the Megaformer machine (also casually referred to as “Pilates on steroids.”) The reformer and springboard classes at Brooklyn Strength have been attracting attention (and big name fans). And, Pilates plays a big part of active recovery at the chic PhysioLogic studio. Plus, the heated class at Hot Pilates made SELF’s list of the best core-toning classes and Lea Michele swears by the transformative classes at @RomneyPilates.

Yes, most of those places might mix trendy with traditional, but hey, isn’t that exactly what SoulCycle and Flywheel have done with regular old group-cycling classes? We think the more options and entry points to the training style, the better.

Just head over to Blogilates Instagram account (with one million other followers) for a glimpse at traditional Pilates exercises blended with founder Cassey Ho’s signature POP style.

Pilates body—still a thing.

The post The Truth About That Pilates Article appeared first on SELF.

]]> http://www.self.com/fitness/fitness-news/2015/09/truth-about-pilates/feed/ 0 Khloé Kardashian Unveils a New Fitness App—and Shares Her Training Secrets http://www.self.com/fitness/fitness-news/2015/09/khloe-kardashian-fitness-app/ http://www.self.com/fitness/fitness-news/2015/09/khloe-kardashian-fitness-app/#comments Tue, 15 Sep 2015 20:15:33 +0000 http://www.self.com/?p=1167843 Fitspiration just got the Kardashian treatment.

The post Khloé Kardashian Unveils a New Fitness App—and Shares Her Training Secrets appeared first on SELF.

]]> What does the woman with the ultimate fitness closet do next? Launch a fitness app! Khloé, along with her sisters Kim, Kourtney, Kendall and Kylie stopped by an NYC Apple store yesterday to celebrate the launch of their five new apps and websites.

Related: Score Your Best Body Ever! 

Each app has a different focus and while Kim’s will highlight her style and OOTD, Khloé’s app (and website KhloeWithaK.com) will be about sharing her fitness journey. She’ll be revealing behind-the-scenes info on what workout leggings she’s sporting, workout selfies, favorite sports bras and videos with trainer Gunnar Peterson.

Related: The Slimming Breakfast Smoothie

The app is free to download but some content will live behind a $2.99 paywall. (Currently Kylie’s app is topping the chart, but Khloé’s is holding strong in the top 20.) Looks like we just scored a new workout buddy—and workout buddies share fitness clothes right? 

The post Khloé Kardashian Unveils a New Fitness App—and Shares Her Training Secrets appeared first on SELF.

]]> http://www.self.com/fitness/fitness-news/2015/09/khloe-kardashian-fitness-app/feed/ 0 Check Out This Toga Party’s Impressive VIP List http://www.self.com/fitness/fitness-news/2015/09/nike-animal-house-parody/ http://www.self.com/fitness/fitness-news/2015/09/nike-animal-house-parody/#comments Tue, 15 Sep 2015 15:10:21 +0000 http://www.self.com/?p=1167790 Olympic athletes and celebs started a massive dance party.

The post Check Out This Toga Party’s Impressive VIP List appeared first on SELF.

]]> Nike threw a massive toga party and the guest list was packed with some major athletic talent. While it makes sense for Nike to pull out the togas whenever they want (Trivia: Nike is the goddess of victory.), the brand debuted the Animal House parody leading up to this past weekend’s University of Oregon’s football game against Michigan State. (More trivia: The original movie was filmed on the Oregon’s campus.)

The party is overflowing with notable alum who have traded their workout wear for Grecian drapes. Check out the dance floor and you’ll spot track stars English Gardener and Mandy White along with football players, ESPN anchors, hall of famers, decathlon world-record holders and 2014 Heisman Trophy winner Marcus Mariota. Not to mention a cameo from lifelong Duck, Ty Burrell of Modern Family.

Check it out below—just do it.

]]> http://www.self.com/fitness/fitness-news/2015/09/nike-animal-house-parody/feed/ 0 Ellie Kemper is Taking Her Fitness Routine to the Next Level http://www.self.com/fitness/fitness-news/2015/09/ellie-kemper-workout-triathlon/ http://www.self.com/fitness/fitness-news/2015/09/ellie-kemper-workout-triathlon/#comments Mon, 14 Sep 2015 20:30:31 +0000 http://www.self.com/?p=1167326 The Unbreakable Kimmy Schmidt star tells us about her triathlon training schedule, speedy race-day goals and her number one motivator (hint: dessert).

The post Ellie Kemper is Taking Her Fitness Routine to the Next Level appeared first on SELF.

]]>

Ellie Kemper, the star of Netflix’s Unbreakable Kimmy Schmidt, has had her fair share of fitness moments on-screen, but she’s taking her off-screen workouts to an entirely new level—and we’re so on board with it! The actress is set to participate in the Nautica Malibu Triathlon on September 20. Kemper will be part of a relay team, tackling the four-mile running portion of the swim-bike-run race in efforts to help raise $1 million for Children’s Hospital Los Angeles’ Pediatric Cancer Research Program. (Her teammates are fellow The Office alums Paul Lieberstein, who played Toby, and Brent Forrester, a producer of the show.) We caught up with Kemper to talk fitness shop. 

SELF: What piqued your interest in triathlons?

Ellie Kemper: I’ve participated in the Nautica Malibu Triathlon a couple of times, but only in the running portion. It feels very cool to be a part of something so uplifting and motivating. On top of that, it benefits an incredible cause.

SELF: What is your training routine like? Are you working with a coach?

EK: I am not working with a coach, and I’m probably doing everything wrong! I have been running three to four days a week, and doing The Bar Method and SoulCycle classes on the other days. I’m trying to keep a good balance.

SELF: Do you train with a partner then? 

EK: No, just my playlist!

SELF: Do you have a goal for race day?

EK: I would love to maintain a sub-8 minute mile pace. That would be a good time for me.

SELF: On days you don’t feel like training, how do you get motivated?

EK: On those days, I have to switch into autopilot mode, and just throw on my workout clothes and head out the door before I can come up with a good reason not to.

SELF: Filming for season 2 of Unbreakable Kimmy Schmidt just started. How are you balancing filming and training? 

EK: I’m trying to work out just about every day, but I’ve been listening to my body, too. When I feel fatigued, I know that sleep is more important than exercise on that particular day.

SELF: What’s been the most rewarding part of the experience?

EK: Keeping a good balance of work, rest, exercise and goal-setting. Also, ice cream at the end of the day always helps.

The post Ellie Kemper is Taking Her Fitness Routine to the Next Level appeared first on SELF.

]]> http://www.self.com/fitness/fitness-news/2015/09/healthy-instagrams-sept-6/feed/ 0 Work Out or the Giraffe Gets It http://www.self.com/fitness/fitness-news/2015/09/giraffe-fitness-app/ http://www.self.com/fitness/fitness-news/2015/09/giraffe-fitness-app/#comments Fri, 04 Sep 2015 17:25:58 +0000 http://www.self.com/?p=1167296 An adorable fitness app is your new motivation to hit the gym on the regular.

The post Work Out or the Giraffe Gets It appeared first on SELF.

]]> Finding the motivation to hit the gym isn’t always an easy task, so naturally we sometimes find excuses to skip the sweat session all together. But this struggle just got a bit easier with the help of a little giraffe.

A new fitness-tracking app called Tep challenges you to walk, run and cycle regularly to keep your adorable pet giraffe alive. You earn coins that can be redeemed for food and drink to keep your pet fed, or for ways to customize it and its environment, such as hats, footwear and backgrounds. 

Similar to the 90’s Tamagotchi pets that challenged kids to raise a pesky little monster from egg to adulthood, Tep brings the nostalgia into the modern day with a fitness twist. Optionally, you can sync Tep with your Fitbit or Jawbone device so that the app doesn’t continuously use your GPS. You can even share workout results like any other fitness tracking app.

So, next time you feel like lounging around, get up and get moving—or the giraffe gets it.

The post Work Out or the Giraffe Gets It appeared first on SELF.

]]> http://www.self.com/fitness/fitness-news/2015/09/giraffe-fitness-app/feed/ 0 Here’s How to Work Out in Hot Weather http://www.self.com/fitness/fitness-news/2015/09/hot-weather-workout-tips-heat-cramps/ http://www.self.com/fitness/fitness-news/2015/09/hot-weather-workout-tips-heat-cramps/#comments Thu, 03 Sep 2015 17:15:11 +0000 http://www.self.com/?p=1167277 When the pros overheat, dehydrate and get injured in record numbers, you know the hot weather can be dangerous. Use these tips to prepare for exercising in high temps.

The post Here’s How to Work Out in Hot Weather appeared first on SELF.

]]> If you’ve been watching the U.S. Open, it’s not just Serena’s powerful and speedy serve that has you in awe. It’s also the number of players who have chosen to retire from their matches due to injuries, overheating, dehydration and cramping. In fact, this year’s Open has already set a record for the most retirements (12 total: 10 men and 2 women) in one round of any Grand Slam tournament. That’s three more than the previous record, set during the 2011 U.S. Open. Crazy, right? Especially since these athletes have worked so hard to be able to compete at this tournament—deciding to not finish is an incredibly tough call to make. 

Even if you’re not competing at Arthur Ashe Stadium in 90-degree heat, you probably have an outdoor run or beach bootcamp class slated for Labor Day Weekend. Or at least you are planning on it. So it’s important to know how to properly prepare and train in these extra-hot, end-of-summer temps. Here are four tips for getting your sweat on safely:

1. Hydrate, hydrate, hydrate! Be sure you’re drinking lots of liquids (ahem, water not rosé) the day before training or playing in the heat. “I always advise athletes to drink before an event so their pee looks like lemonade, not apple juice, and not water,” says Dr. Nadya Swedan, MD, FAAPMR, physical medicine and rehabilitation specialist for sports injuries in New York City. Urine color is a quick and easy way to check in with your health—a dark yellow color is often a sign of dehydration.

2. Get acclimated. “You’ll want to methodically increase the duration and intensity of your workouts,” says Andia Winslow, founder of #WinslowWay Conditioning and senior coach, at Mile High Run Club. Aim to be in the climate you’ll be training in at least a week beforehand, she advises. But if you’re at the beach for a long weekend and still want to log a training session, just shorten your workout and try to save it for early morning or early evening when temps are typically a few degrees cooler.

3. Set realistic expectations. The heat makes everything more difficult (as if you needed the reminder), so it’s important to recognize that ahead of time. “Athletes often get frustrated that they cannot perform as fast or go for as long as they can in comfortable temperatures,” says Erin Ward, instructor at the hot yoga studio Y7 in New York City. The best advice? “Be patient,” and perhaps move your run indoors on those extra steamy days. If it’s outdoors or bust be on the lookout for signs of heat exhaustion including heavy sweating, dizziness, nausea, headache and more.

4. If you start to cramp, don’t ignore it. Heat cramps tend to result in painful muscle spasms and thought to be caused by dehydration and the loss of electrolytes that occurs during training, specifically in hot temps.“Cramping can also be a sign of improper training or an injured muscle,” says Dr. Sweden. She suggests preventing them by eating foods rich in potassium and magnesium, like bananas. However, if you experience muscle spasms and tightness during training, there’s no shame in taking a break, explains Winslow. 

We’ll be looking for the sun and bicep emojis in Instagram!

The post All Hail Serena! appeared first on SELF.

]]>

Powerful, captivating, impressive, unmatched—Serena Williams is one of the (perhaps the) most dominate athletes of all time, and all eyes are on her as she competes for a calendar-year Grand Slam title at the U.S. Open.

To celebrate each of Williams’ 21 major wins, Gatorade commissioned artists from across the globe to create one massively epic mural in Brooklyn, New York. The collection, titled “Serena 21” was hand-painted on a wall in Williamsburg; see a snapshot of it above, and footage of how it was created here.

Gatorade has also just released an ad that includes inspiring vintage footage of Williams that will give you chills. The video takes you on a journey, showcasing the intensity and passion Williams brings to the tennis courts.

Now let’s make it 22 wins.

[h/t: ESPN W]
